title: Effects of Light Intensity on Tropical Plant Growth
abstract: This study investigates the relationship between photosynthetic active radiation and biomass production in tropical plant species under controlled conditions.
hypothesis: Increased light intensity will lead to higher biomass production and improved photosynthetic efficiency in tropical plants.
methodology: Three tropical plant specimens were exposed to varying light intensities (40%, 70%, 100%) for 30 days. Growth measurements were taken daily.
results: Plants exposed to 70% light intensity showed optimal growth with 25% increase in biomass compared to 40% light. 100% light caused photoinhibition.
conclusions: Moderate light intensity (70%) provides optimal conditions for tropical plant growth, while excessive light can be detrimental.
